qas.question: What three groups were the first to diverge from angiosperm?
What term refers to the first three groups to diverge from angiosperm?
How clear is the relationship between the broadest of the three non-basal angiosperm groups?
What group do some analyses seem to indicate diverged first?
What were the first three groups to diverge from magnoliids?
What do Amborellales tend to group with instead of monocots?
What is the status of the relationship between Nymphaeales and monocots?
What attitude is there about the first magnoliids diverging from the ancestral angiosperm?
What do some eudicots indicate diverged first?

context: The exact relationship between these eight groups is <b6_0>not yet clear<b6_0/>, although there is <b7_0>agreement<b7_0/> that the first three groups to diverge from the ancestral angiosperm were <a0_0><b4_0>Amborellales, Nymphaeales, and Austrobaileyales<b4_0/><a0_0/>. The term <a1_0>basal<a1_0/> angiosperms refers to these three groups. Among the rest, the relationship between the three broadest of these groups (magnoliids, monocots, and eudicots) remains <a2_0>unclear<a2_0/>. Some analyses make the <a3_0><b8_0>magnoliids<b8_0/><a3_0/> the first to diverge, others the monocots. Ceratophyllum seems to group with <b5_0>the eudicots<b5_0/> rather than with the monocots.
